bibl.title: Governmental control of guardianship over minors in Roman Egypt
bibl.note: Local state officials in Roman Egypt possessed quite far-reaching competences and possibilities to control guardianships of minors. However, they relied not on information they collected themselves but on that supplied by the population.
bibl.seg: Thomas Kruse, Governmental Control of Guardianship over Minors in Roman Egypt.

Uri Yiftach & Michele Faraguna (edd.), Legal Documents in Ancient Societies. VI. Ancient Guardianship: Legal Incapacities in the Ancient World. Jerusalem, 3-5.11.2013 = Graeca Tergestina. Storia e civilt√†. 4 (Trieste, 2017) pp. 175-188.

Local state officials in Roman Egypt possessed quite far-reaching competences and possibilities to control guardianships of minors. However, they relied not on information they collected themselves but on that supplied by the population.
